posts.com:
>>27955766
I work in 3D and visual effects, self taught, went to school for mathematics. You cope by learning how to use the new tools, and putting them in your resume so you don’t get left behind.

Honestly, they seem like magic on the surface, and the constant fear mongering certainly isn’t helping, but after you use it for a while, you realize it’s really just fancy photoshop with a concept art generation function. It’s like having access to a jr concept artist, and an advanced photoshop pro for free.

Honestly everyone who’s a professional should be super into this, because it lets you speed through a lot of the things you do professionally, and gives you more time to either take up more work, or work on personal art. The biggest gripe I had with doing art professionally was never having time to make what I wanted, and now that’s gone. Life is good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27955766
It's understandable to feel concerned about the rapid advancement of technology and its potential impact on employment. However, it's important to keep in mind that while some jobs may be automated or replaced by AI, new job opportunities will also emerge as a result of technological advancements. It's also important to remember that you are more than just your job or career. There are many other aspects of life that can bring meaning and fulfillment, such as hobbies, relationships, and personal growth.

It's also important to focus on developing skills that are uniquely human, such as creativity, critical thinking, communication, and empathy. These skills are difficult for AI to replicate and will likely be in high demand in the future.

Finally, it's important to keep an open mind and be willing to adapt and learn new things. While it's natural to feel uncertain about the future, the key is to stay positive and proactive. Take steps to improve your skills and knowledge, and consider seeking out opportunities for professional development and learning. Don't let your fears hold you back from pursuing your goals and aspirations.

So, I have a wife, let's call her "Hobbit".

Company X and Company Y do somewhat similar things (health related) but have different client profiles, so sometimes there is some collaboration.

There's this high position woman in Company Y, let's call her "Sally", who is familiar with my work and offered me a great position, which I gladly took. Basically I'll get paid ~48% more for doing a combination/integration of job A + job B and there aren't many people in town with the necessary set of skills... so I'm in!

Here's the catch: Company Y is a pain in the ass regarding hiring people with romantic relationships with another employee.
Sally KNOWS I'm married to Hobbit, and thus told me
>at least for the first semester, try to pretend you met Hobbit at work, so if in the future you're seen together you can just tell you're dating and my superiors will tolerate it... otherwise it'll look bad on me

Hobbit and I will work in different parts in the same building (so only briefly meet during breaks and such). Since Hobbit already has many friends outside work, she doesn't have a close relarionship with any workmate, which makes things easier. Still, we've been in a couple of gatherings with her coworkers before and there's a (small) chance some of them might recognize me.

Sally knows Hobbit and I can't LARP forever (eventually people will see us somewhere or find something on social media, etc), so she thinks the best course of action would be indeed pretending we started seeing each other some time after I started. Apparently, Sally is sure the CEOs will overlook it if they eventually think that's what happened.

Any hints on how to keep this LARP as convincing as possible for as long as possible? Has someone here being in a similar situation before?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because it's irrational and genuinely tragic.

1. You're not taking into account what it means to not exist for a billion+ plus years past this point. You're thinking about the absense of pain from death, but you're not contemplating death itself enough and what it actually means for you.
2. Some decades are a nothing-burger to struggle through compared to the infinity of death
3. There is probably a lot of good in your life you are taking for granted. Things that seem simple and arbitrary until you lose them.
4. You are very likely under-estimating your ability to improve your life for the better
5. Life paths are impossible to predict, it is easy for external events to change your circumstances for the better
6. Major depression doesn't last long statistically. It tends to naturally ease-up over some weeks/months if you wait it out
7. The odds of fucking up your suicide are high. More people try and get damaged permanently from it than try and succeed
8. In general, most peoples' lives are a lot better than they think they are. A lot of people lead to believe they have bad lives are brought to that point because they feel deficient compared to others in some way. They get so obsessed with comparison, they genuinely lose the ability to see the good

>>27955971

Happy you find it helpful
Yah it's a big universe out there, and the conditions of our existence are surreal. It's a miracle we're alive at all among billions of light years of empty space and inert matter.
It can be easy to get caught up in the minutia of our lives and let it overwhelm us. The reality is that despite the vastness of what you've been born into, there's nobody quite like you out there. The constituent parts that compose you have been migrating since the dawn of time across great distances to eventually form the being you are today. Like a complex but brilliant sort of flame, it would be tragic if it was snuffed out prematurely.

I've had functional depression myself for a while now, whenever it starts to flare up a bit and turn into major depression that list of stuff is pretty effective at snapping me out of it. Haven't had an episode for a long time now. IMO stopping suicidal ideation helps a lot when it comes to preventing severe depression.

Treating depression spikes like a medical condition helps too imo. Kind of like a mental version of the flu. Remembering that it's temporary, that there a things that can be done to ameliorate it. Taking it a bit easy, getting therapy for a few months, watching a bunch of comfort shows or doing something distracting etc.

>Is dating down a bad idea?
"Dating down" is a concept sort of invented by a class of people who have a very one-dimensional view of relationships. The entire point of dating and relationships is that the person you're with compliments you. They compensate for the things that you lack and look to you for support for things that they lack. Maybe you make more money than her but she's better at building friendship circles than you. Maybe she sucks at organizing but you're really good at it. Maybe you hate cleaning the bathroom but she's willing to do it. Maybe you know more about ancient history and math than her but she's a really good musician and knows a lot about that. >>27957265
You never HAVE to scream back. You guys are in a shitty relationship if that’s what you view as being a minor argument. Seek anger management and leave the relationship as you are both incapable of behaving as adults if you’re both yelling over some dumb shit. You are annoyed by her and she’s annoyed by you.

My best advice is say this:

“Hey, can you come here and sit on the couch/bed with me? I think we need to have a talk. I am not going to yell or get angry anymore.

I am tired of living this way. I don’t feel like it’s appropriate for us to take our anger out on each other with our behavior. I’m uncomfortable with how you go silent for long periods of time and I feel like it’s a punishment instead of a solution to our problem.

I am at an unhappy place in my life right now and I feel like our interactions are a part of my problems currently. I think I need to get some help to deal with my anger issues. I want better for my life than what we have right now.

We can work on this together, if you still want to. But we have to work together. I want you to be happy too, but we can’t keep an unhealthy, co-dependent relationship. It’s not good for either of us.”

Then you sign up for therapy, maybe even couples therapy and work out your issues there. Otherwise, you simply need to break up because you don’t need to live a miserable life.

https://headspace.org.au/explore-topics/supporting-a-young-person/after-exposure-to-traumatic-event/

To help young people through the process of recovery, there are some things that you can do:

Acknowledge the trauma that they have experienced– let them know that you are there for them and are ready to listen and support them.

Provide information about common reactions to traumatic experiences and normalise their physical and emotional responses.

Encourage them to spend time with family, friends and other trusted people.

Limit their access to media coverage of the traumatic event – information is important, but too much can reinforce distress.

Encourage them to re-establish their normal routines such as mealtimes, sleep, work, study and relaxation.

Join them in doing enjoyable activities.

Let them talk about their experience when they feel ready. This can help them to begin to make sense of what has happened and to try to understand what it means for them and their life.

Alright I'll give you a proper answer, although I'm still finding my career so take this with a grain of salt.

Asses yourself, think about where you are and where you want to be in the near future. Take into account what matters more, a higher wage, a high standard of living, more time with family, more time with friends, good benefits maybe? Each choice leads to different consequences, a higher paying job may come with more stressors, a lower paying job may grant you more leeway.

Now think about what interest you the most! What field do you think would work best for you? Not decided, we'll in that case think more generally. If your not sure exactly what you want to do specifically try a lower level entry job somewhere in that field for you to dip your feet and go from there.

This is where I'm at, I've worked multiple odd jobs in my field and am currently over a year in a nice place, good pay but extremely boring. I'm now also at a dividing path, do I want to continue working with well paying bland job or do I want to potentially sacrifice my efforts for something more interesting to me.

I'm still undecided too, but I think I'll start looking for new places after the holidays c:

Best of luck out there

I worked at a friend's business while I went to college, and practiced 3D art and VFX on my own time, and I practiced until I became skilled enough that I outclassed most of the other people on upwork, and then through COVID I had to drop out of college, and started taking upwork jobs, and on my 2nd job, the people liked me so much that they recruited me into a management position permanently. And from there I had management experience, so it became easier to find non-freelance work.

To be clear, they didn't like me for my art. Anyone can do that. Hell, AI can do most of it now. No, they liked me because they like working with ME. Practice your people skills, and you'll go far. You don't even really need to know what you're doing half of the time.

And don't kiss ass. nobody likes a kiss ass. especially people at the top of the ladder who spend all day having their ass kissed.

>>27949614
Meditation is a way that we can basically do good deeds.

So you know that when you do what you should do you do good things you feel good.

And what you feel when you do what you shouldn't do and what you feel when you do bad things you feel bad.

So meditation is just like the highest good deed it's a very strong powerful way to deepen the mind and the heart and be skillful because it's like we're training our mind.

So there are a lot of different ways to go about doing good deeds it's not just meditation.

It can be generosity, taking care of your body taking care of your mind, watching what kind of content you consume....

Especially generosity and doing good things for other people That's a big way to help yourself out and help your mind if you're just starting off.

Meditation can be quite difficult so you have to have a lot of intentionality you have to have a lot of sincerity to really get involved with meditation practice.

But for those people who aren't really ready to practice meditation you can still listen to talks from high level OGs in the meditation world and that's going to juice you up 100%

just like listening to LeBron James talk about basketball face-to-face hard to heart is going to juice you up when it comes to playing basketball.

There are LeBron James level Masters of the mind Masters of compassion Masters of transforming suffering so you want to connect with those kind of people.

Thich Nhat Hanh, Ajahn Brahm are a couple names you can look into


Also you can listen to guided meditations that can help a lot if they are coming from a good source.

So you've got to refresh and restart.

And how we set a higher standard for how we live and what we embody is really by being exposed to people who are on a deeper level have gotten even more involved than we have.

So if you are really serious about self-improvement especially in terms of the mind one of the things that you can do is attend meditation retreat, you can see if there's any Buddhist temples in your area that you could visit, and really the focus of that is to bring a quality of exploration to your life.

Going outside of your boundaries and being exposed to a new experiences that are going to set a new standard for what's possible.

The issue that we can easily fall into is that we get stuck in a certain way of living a certain way of seeing the world a certain kind of environment and then we just lock ourselves to think that that's the way that things are so you never really grow or mature.

It's actually that exploration that curiosity that questioning that brings us to investigate life more deeply but we have to do that as a practice it's not just about thinking or even consuming some kind of psychedelic.

You really got to be willing to follow and open yourself up to other perspectives other positions other people.

We all fall into those times right where we are in a very difficult and confusing situation and that's the opportunity to refresh and restart That's the opportunity to begin again to begin new 100% completely new experience completely new life and to do that all we need to do is come back to our breathing become aware of the present moment and take a step from a place of good intention.

>>27950571
So long-term the understanding is that practicing that way will lead to more instability confusion and self fixation unless it's done under the guidance of a experienced teacher.

That's the Buddhist perspective at least.

Secular meditation is completely okay.

Try to emphasize loving kindness, simplicity consistency, concentration and relaxation those should be at the heart of any meditation practice.

The more complicated it is the more wrong it is unless you're working directly with someone who you really trust and is very experienced in a particular avenue of meditation.

But even then I would recommend using the rule of simplicity is legitimacy.

>>27950770

It's really easy to get stuck in our complicated thinking.

Actually our story and our thoughts is not so important.

We should try to emphasize having a view that's based on present moment mindfulness and doing good deeds.

So if we find that we have a deep habit of being stuck on our complicated thinking and are self fixated view, then we should try to practice generosity and do more good deeds.

There is a particular view that we can have that is not about someone or something or sometime or someplace.

But rather to experience only here in the present moment and we can deepen and empower that view over time.

But the foundation of being able to do that is that we're involved in morality we're involved in doing good deeds were involved in living a meaningful life.

That helps to stabilize and simplify our mind and to help us be more practical and grounded.

You can totally transform the situation and free yourself but you have to start with doing good deeds meditation letting go.

>>27953724
So in Buddhism we can say that Buddhism itself is a practice.

So I'll answer your question in that regard.

The question of what is the practice regarding understanding the true nature of the self in Buddhism is very much based in dropping our assumption of what the self is.

Maybe there is a self maybe there is not a self, what is the self?

And immediately all those assumptions and preconceived notions we have about self-identity and story and I like to say a real true character and a real true story All those come up and then we begin this practice of dropping those assumptions willing to put them down and then looking into the situation that we find ourselves in right now.

So what exactly is this self?

And for me when I look into this situation I find that yes I'm aware of this " " real true person and a real true story...

But when I drop that assumption there is a kind of present moment looking and present moment experiencing.

This doesn't seem to rely on someone or something or some particular time or some particular place.

But it's actually a kind of curiosity a kind of exploration looking into present moments sensations, present moment mental formations,. Feelings in the body, The seeing capacity the hearing capacity...

So we actually investigate the case The present moment situation and that's how we unravel this fixed notion of this real true person in a real true story.


In that way in Buddhism we have a teaching on no self or non-self which means that what you are is not separate from anything else, and also that everything that makes up so-called you " " is not separate from the Sun the environment from all the other people from everything.

This is a teaching known as interbeing.

And we understand this as being a certain kind of like mark of reality not so much a philosophy or belief.

It's absolutely not "we just do it less". Doing it even once is one of the most serious possible offenses.

>do you guys masturbate?
should be a very straightforward
>no, we're forbidden to masturbate
rather than some meandering nonsense about "oh masturbation feels good but it's not good for us"

>what is the middle path bro
You live in an incredibly degenerate period of history. I don't mean that in the /pol/ meme sense of the term "degenerate" but simply that what is considered moderate today would be considered extremely radical by people living during the time of the Buddha.

The middle path is the middle between hedonism and asceticism but you need to seriously consider what those terms mean in the context of Buddhism. The Buddha only gave up on asceticism when he was close to literally starving himself to death. The middle path is not
>oh it's ok to masturbate sometimes we don't want you to do something so extreme as never masturbating
but rather
>It's ok to take care of the basics of food, clothing, and shelter. Living naked under a tree while starving yourself will not help your spiritual progress

Regardless,
>I'm also not a no-fun-allowed wannabe monk either.
I did say that attempting to follow the Pāṭimokkha as much as reasonably possible was for a "serious lay practitioner" and not something to do if you're less serious. But if you're serious about making progress, pretty much everything that is forbidden to monastics is stuff that you wouldn't want to do regardless of whether it was against the rules or not. The relevant stuff is all just dont lie, dont steal, dont kill, dont engage in sexual activity, dont agitate against other people. That's basically all of the first two most serious classes of offenses right there and all of them are actively detrimental to your spiritual progress.

The root of all relationship problems is when people are not at their core, acting with integrity.

I think most abuse in marriages occurs when people settle (marrying someone knowing you don’t love them makes it so much easier to cheat, if you don’t genuinely enjoy someone’s company and or love them you will become very bored and unsatisfied and seek stimulation). One or both partners become resentful of the other for being someone they are settling for. It will begin to sink in that’s all they’ll ever have.

For abusive men with complexes, usually they marry someone below them in some way, usually financially and in other aspects as well. Someone who is below their league will be the only one to put up with their abuse, and they can also have full control of the situation. This can only really be done if someone lacks a conscience, as any pure and gentle person couldn’t stomach using someone so instrumentally and then discarding them after they give you their all (which in these cases is usually several child births).

Cheating occurs due to greed and lack of morals as well. Either they got into a relationship knowing this person is not the one, or somewhere along the way they decided that. I find most people have a very poor sense of loyalty or commitment and views relationships as completely disposable. This is likely a product of our society, as well as because the people who breed are often selfish, inconsiderate, narcissistic assholes.

Loyal people who get disappointed over and over again by others become disloyal. Even if you are a quiet kind hearted pure romance seeker, eventually you will be disappointed enough and may become cruel. If you have always been desirable and attractive and treated as better throughout your life, you are also more likely to use people.

I’ve been bottling up feelings for a childhood friend.

I wish she’d move back over here and start dating me and we’d get married, and everything would be awesome.

I mean seriously, her brother and I are already super close friends, her dad loves me for some reason, and i swear her mom tried to set us up once when we were teenagers like some kind of arranged marriage.

I thought I was over it, but I caught myself staring at her for like half a second too long tonight, and suddenly had to bottle up a whole bunch of feelings. It’s not fair, this never happens to me for random girls out in the public who I’d be fine approaching and asking out. Although it does seem like you've lost something in your efforts, a destressor, a motivator. A hobby perhaps? To me it seems you're missing a hobby to motivate your efforts.

Studying and exercising are great, although can get boring and repetitive. A hobby or interest that you can some home or invest extra cash into seems like a healthy option.

I'd recommend taking the time to see what things interest you most, maybe something you thought of doing in the past but never got into. Try picking something up or checking if there are any workshops or events revolving around it in your area. That way you can learn more about it and meet people interested in whatever that new hobby may be at the same time :)

Now get out there and find a new passion!

posts.sub: I've become depressed and I don't know why
posts.com: I'm trying to take care of myself. I've been self improoving for the past two years and now I'm focusing on diet and fitness. But suddenly I'm very depressed and feel like killing myself. It's difficult to create good habits when I just feel like dying. Has anyone else experienced this? What should I do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nice job on the last two years. It’s really difficult to self- improve so let’s pause and take a moment to appreciate the accomplishment. A great celebration to breathe in through your nose for ten seconds, hold it for ten seconds, then exhale out your mouth for ten seconds. Try this twice. Pace your breathing.

Once we’ve celebrated, let’s consider the present, the moment. Catalog your feelings. You have every reason to be happy about your accomplishment. Why are you depressed? Why do you feel like you don’t belong here?

If you find an answer, use it to make you stronger so these feelings are held in check. These feelings can be good to help you identify problems, but never let them be more than that.

I am going through a similar situation, I came to /adv/ tonight to see if I was alone. I love this board because I see that we are not alone. We have each other.

Diet and exercise sound great, good luck with it. Don’t push too hard at first, consistency is your best friend, even if it’s small.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27943660
>How dumb is it to leave my wife for this
Very.
It's not always a bad idea to end a marriage. It's an incredibly fucking stupid idea to do it impulsively without working on fixing the things that bother you first. If you had no children I'd say sure, go for it. But you do, and that leaves you with a mountain of responsibility and one of those responsibilities is to provide a stable, loving environment where they can grow up in and flourish. I don't care if you don't like it, come to terms with it. Seek out marriage counselling, talk with your wife, don't be resentful towards her and especially your child. Don't think of it as being doomed to stay with her forever, divorce is still an option, but you should explore every other avenue that is available to you first (short of cheating) and genuinely try to fix things before you go down that path. If nothing works and you do end up getting divorced, your number one priority over EVERYTHING ELSE is still the well-being of your child. I don't care if the process of divorce left you hating the mother, you'll not insult her, demean her or try to torpedo her life or relationship with her child - you support her to support your child. I don't care if you have a nice dinner date set up with your new partner, if your child is having a stage play at school, you go - whether it's playing the lead role or a tree in the background. If it's daddy weekend (assuming the child will stay with the mother) it means that all other obligations, short of emergencies and things that are necessary for survival, take a backseat.
Think about this long and hard, OP. Making it an impulse decision is the stupidest thing you could do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27954115
It can be difficult to feel like you are an embarrassment to your friends and family, and it may be tempting to want to cut them out of your life and start over somewhere else. However, it's important to remember that your friends and family care about you and want what is best for you, even if they may not always agree with you or understand how you feel.

It's natural to feel like you want to distance yourself from others when you are struggling, but it's important to remember that relationships can be a source of support and can help you through difficult times. Instead of cutting your friends and family out of your life, it may be more helpful to try to communicate with them and seek their support.

If you feel like you are unable to communicate effectively with your friends and family or if you are struggling with feelings of embarrassment, it may be helpful to seek the support of a mental health professional. They can help you work through your feelings and develop healthy ways of coping with difficult emotions.

It's also important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way, and that many people struggle with similar feelings at different points in their lives. It can be helpful to reach out to friends, family, or a support group for support and guidance.

Ultimately, it's important to remember that you are in control of your own life and have the power to make decisions that are best for you. If you feel like you need to make a change in your life, it may be helpful to consider your options and make a plan that is right for you

One of my favorite stories of all time
I Was a civilian contractor with the Activity - basically Military Intelligence Special Forces. Card-carrying geniuses with 145+ IQs who were also experts in weapons, explosives, etc.
I managed some of their bleeding-edge electronics and had asked the manufacturers to send down some experts to answer questions. Three civilians come in - an obvious engineer in cargo pants and a polo, a woman in an expensive pantsuit and heels with major makeup, and a guy in a $2k suit. All from the manufacturer. So I take them to the unit's common rom to meet the experts
I introduce them to Sgt "Smith", Sgt "Jones" and Sgt "White". They ere watching NASCAR on TV when we came in. Smith had a spit cup for the chewing tobacco in his mouth. Jones was literally playing a banjo, and White had been reading a D&D book
Smith greets them with a thick as fuck Alabama accent. Jones a Georgia accent. White = Carolina. Big smiles
The civilians are obviously bored, ask me
>"Where are the experts from the Activity?"
These ARE the experts. The engineer tentatively asks what the questions were.
Cue a 3 hour deep-dive into wave propagation theory, Huygen's Principle, and mapping out electronic circuits on a white board along with a ton of calculus. When the soldiers learned the well-dressed man and woman were *sales* they blew them off.
The engineer cursed in German so White switched to German to continue speaking with him.
I was grinning at the stunned look on their faces and explained
All three of the sergeants were electronic warfare specialists that were also trained linguists, cryptographers, and intelligence analysts. And they were all looking forward to deer hunting season.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27955900
Learn C#, Java, C++ or possibly Rust. Learn associated engines with whatever language you choose.
The reason I tell you this is what with some 3D modelling experience and good programming experience, you're a natural fit for game development. You'll be able to sell yourself on several major aspects, namely game design, model design, and development of both (make up more fancy words if you want). And as for the above languages, they're practically industry standard for AAA games. I especially see C# a lot, though it may only be this country.
If you want to go the extra mile, figure out what GUI libraries are the most used professionally for your language of choice, and learn it. That way you'll be an interesting candidate for a technical design role.
You're going to want to find a group in your university which does development in your language on the spare time. Internships only gets you so far, you want to tell your employer you're willing to work on passion projects in programming alongside your studies. If there aren't any, create one (leadership experience is better). Make some not-too-complicated game in Unity, something that, worst case, becomes an early access game on Steam. That'll be part of your pitch in interviews.
>t. Physics grad who hates physics and became a C++ software developer purely by learning it in spare time

The other day he showed up late again which caused me to sit alone in a nice busy restaurant for 25 minutes, sipping on tea and thumbing my asshole while everyone around me was having a great time. He didn't even shoot me a message to say he'd be a bit late. I felt really embarrassed, as if everyone around me thought I was the guy that got stood up on a date, even though that's not the case. He finally arrives and we finish the rest of the evening with no problems, because he's actually a nice guy. But I had a bitter taste in my mouth.

This has been going on for years and has affected other members of the group as well. That night at the restaurant was my last straw. I'm considering whether or not I should call him out for his behavior. I literally don't know anyone else like this.

Should I muddy the waters or should I let sleeping dogs lie?

posts.com: I had clinical depression while in college. I barely ended up graduating with a 2.2 GPA. My freshman and sophomore years were disasters. In my junior year I stepped it up because the dean told me I need a 2.0 minimum to keep going. I started all my projects and homework the day they were assigned to give me as much time as possible. I also enrolled in some easier courses to help my GPA out. I took a few courses I failed over again to get a better grade. Also I took some courses over winter and summer break to boost my GPA too. I fucked up my senior year because my depression was bad but I had a job lined up so I didn't really care. Not sure what your major is but I did CS which allowed me to get experience doing IT jobs on campus as well as internships. Job and internship experience can help make up for your bad GPA and it probably saved me.

>>27954772
I had this same problem. My number of withdrawn classes is in the 20s. But I am now on my last year. I had no motivation, didn't give enough of a shit to show up.

Basically you first need to realize that you can do it. It's so easy. All it takes is to show up to class everyday and to do the assignments one by one. It's not going to take all of your free time to do this. I'm in engineering school, I work 30+ hours a week and it still only takes me a few hours a week to get everything done. Once you realize that it's completely within your power to do this, all you need is a reason to do it. My reason is because I decided I needed to be a person who others can rely on. So I need to make money and have a useful skillset. I decided it was selfish to waste my life, because my life could be used to support my loved ones instead of being a burden on them. That is my reason. Maybe it will work for you too.

My family tree on both sides is riddled with mental health issues - bipolar, clinical depression, clinical anxiety, etc. One side of my family has famous last name and our mental health struggles are literally documented on the fucking internet. >Talking about problems doesn't do jack shit if your problem is physical.
I struggled under the weight of war trauma, abuse, and genetics for decades. You know what helped me instantly? The correct medication. So I don't know what your symptoms are OP, but my recommendation is this:
>Go get psychiatrically evaluated
>Investigate and evaluate your medical options
>Then, after medication, go to therapy
Therapy alone is going to waste years of your life with minimal results. Get evaluated first.

don't move out while you're going to school. at least wait to graduate.

from my personal experience, make sure you have a job you like and make a good enough amount of money to pay for an apartment on your own. if you can't do that, DON'T MOVE OUT. Don't sublease. Don't pretend its okay if its with roommates and you pay a smaller portion. Don't feel guilty or shame for living at home with parents. You're super lucky they aren't charging rent. Mine do, $500 a month. Way better than anything else around my area.

Also make sure that you have goals. Focus on actual goals for yourself rather than 'what it feels you have to do'. Moving out isn't a goal, it's what you do when you need to reach a goal. You move to a new place if you get a new job, or find a gf. don't just move out cause it feels like you have to (if your parents suck then i would, but it sounds like they're nice if they're not charging rent)

spend this time developing yourself. Social, mental, physical, wealth, skills, hobbies, etc.

I'm in the same situation but finished school. I have my hobbies but some are stunted by my living situation.

Ditto with a partner, I feel like it's hard to seriously date here but people would be more understanding given the situation around the country/covid.

My advice to you is it depends on your goals. What parts of personal growth are halted for you? Can you fix that while living at home?

If the things you want can't be fixed and you value your own space more than the money you'll save, move out.

Honestly I'd go on a "vacation" and see how you handle it. Rent an airbnb somewhere you'd like to live, or take an actual vacation in one and try to simulate a lifestyle.
